Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: PPER: Microplastic AWARENESS Program: Amplifying Water-quality Analysis Research Experiences for Northwest Indiana Educators, Students and Society

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Microplastics are small plastic particles (less than 5 millimeters in diameter) in the environment, and they can come from a variety of sources. This research project is designed to utilize citizen scientists from a local middle school to collect data on microplastic pollution and integrate its detection into water quality monitoring. Project researchers will train and work with undergraduate science education research students, local teachers, and students (citizen scientists) in water quality research to study microplastic pollution in the Lake Michigan watershed. Citizen scientists will be trained to 1) conduct traditional water quality monitoring procedures, 2) quantify and study the transport and fate of microplastic pollutants and 3) determine the extent of microplastic materials consumed by common macroinvertebrates in the watershed. This large data set collection, which can be compiled effectively using citizen scientists, is also necessary for microplastic pollution mitigation strategies.

Microplastic pollution is created from a number of sources and is defined as plastic waste materials less than 5 millimeters in diameter. This pollution is considered a threat on a global level due to the abundance, persistence and mobility of these plastic materials. While many studies have been performed on microplastic pollution have in the marine environment, recent scientific reports conclude that more research is necessary, especially in freshwater ecosystems. The project researchers are expanding upon traditional water quality monitoring by quantifying and analyzing the microplastic pollution in the local Lake Michigan watershed through the development of a citizen science program. The research includes investigations on the degree of uptake of microplastics by common macroinvertebrates in local headwater streams and the probable effects on these organisms. The full extent of microplastic pollution on organisms and humans is not yet known and additional research is required to address many unknown aspects of these pollutants. The project includes training of citizen scientists from a local public middle school. The project also provides an opportunity for the community to take part in critical research on current stresses to freshwater systems. Undergraduate science major students are taking part in the multi-disciplinary research and are being challenged with teaching research methods to the middle school citizen scientists as part of their teacher education preparation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF-funded Microplastic AWARENESS Program trained over 70 young citizen scientists, their middle school science teachers and several undergraduate research students to collect traditional water quality data and study the emerging pollutants in the classification of microplastics. Specifically, synthetic microfiber pollution was assessed in the Salt Creek Watershed in Northwest Indiana, which is part of the greater Lake Michigan watershed. The study was the first in this Lake Michigan watershed to measure the amount of synthetic microfibers discharged from wastewater treatment plants or originating from other sources, which distribute through the tributaries and watershed and the lake. The young citizen scientists also explored the effects of the microscopic pollutants on organisms living in the watershed through controlled experimentation in the classroom.  In the university setting, a few hundred undergraduate students learned about the microplastics pollution problem through freshmen chemistry and biology laboratory experiments in context with the watershed investigations. 

Greater awareness of the importance of water quality monitoring and protection of fresh water resources through field, classroom and laboratory activities was a significant outcome of the funded project, and a complete set of data was collected over the course of the project. Middle school science students and teachers were trained to collect traditional water quality data, and to sample water, sediment and air. The problem of plastic pollution was addressed and studied in relation to water quality and watershed health. For each field excursion, students collected garbage and identified the types of plastic. Four additional sets of data were collected on the physical, chemical, biological and geological parameters for the studied site in the Salt Creek watershed; three additional sites were monitored by undergraduate research students. The water and sediment samples were used to assess the quantity of synthetic microfibers, the most common microplastic pollution, in the natural environment. The contaminants were found in all of the sediment samples, very few were collected from the air monitors and the water samples were examined by using the total suspended solids (TSS) filters. After chemical processing to remove organic debris and natural fibers, the modified filter contents were analyzed under the microscope for synthetic microfibers. From the 122 surface water samples, 86% contained synthetic microfibers, with an average of 8 synthetic microfibers per 4 L of water. While the expectation was that the water downstream from the wastewater treatment plants would contain significantly more microfibers than the upstream water, the data did not support this.

Laboratory experiments were designed and implemented from the funded project. The young citizen scientists explored the responses of living organisms to their exposure to blue polyester microfibers.  Specific batches of different aquatic organisms, such as snails and crustaceans, were exposed to the blue polyester fibers while others were monitored in controlled environments, free of the synthetic microfibers. From the results of the studies, it is possible that the blue polyester microfibers are linked to a disruption in reproduction processes and may function as endocrine disruptors. University students performed experiments in their undergraduate laboratory courses, and investigated biological effects of synthetic microfibers or the presence of these pollutants in sediments and soil samples. The chemistry laboratory experiment was published in the Journal of Chemical Education.

Teacher training for undergraduate students pursuing science education careers and teacher development were important outcomes of the project. Teachers and science education students took part in research experiences, which provided valuable content learning; curriculum units were created for the formative watershed monitoring program. Furthermore, relationships were developed and the watershed monitoring continues as part of the 8th grade science curriculum. The school-university partnership model for watershed monitoring is expanding to include additional area schools.
